page.title: 13 Forestry in Lamberhurst
page.content: The mixed{coniferous}and{deciduous} woodland in{Lamberhurst}is mainly owned by the Bayham Abbey and Scotney Castle estates. Every 15 years{chestnut}needs to be{ {coppiced,}which means the trunk is cut near ground level. The chestnut stem crop is used for spikes, hop poles and fences. Other timber is sold to Norway where it is turned into pulp and returned to England for paper making. {Birch}and{ash}are grown, ash often for tool handles.{Larch, spruce}and{Scots {pine}are softwoods used in building. British spruce is weak so rarely used. { Beech}and{oak}are hardwoods which also support a wide variety of wildlife. Oak used to be used for gateposts, beams and shipbuilding, but is now too expensive because of it's slow rate of growth. A full-time woodman is employed at Scotney.
